title: 3D Printing Part 2: Intro to 3D Modeling
description:
Recommended prerequisite: 3D Printing Part 1

Want to create your own models to 3D print in the Makers Lab?

Join Makers Lab staff for the second pop-up in a three-part series covering the basics of 3D design & modeling using the web-based application Tinkercad. This pop-up is for beginners, but all skills levels are welcome to attend.

After attending the 90-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Design a basic 3D model in Tinkercad
  2. Export a model out of Tinkercad for 3D printing
  3. Locate resources for continuing your learning with Tinkercad
  4. Identify other 3D design & modeling software for more advanced projects

Make sure to sign up for a Tinkercad account before the pop-up and use a three-button if you have one available. You don't even need to download Tinkercad, it is a free, web-based application that you can use anywhere, as long as you have an internet connection.

Need to design 3D models with more complex geometries? Attend an upcoming Fusion 360 pop-up! Unsure if Tinkercad is the right software for your project? Contact the Makers Lab for suggestions.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Data Science Help Desk
description:
Visit our virtual data science help desk! 

Introducing the Data Science Help Desk, a place to ask your general questions about data science including how to download software or code packages, prep for upcoming data science classes, get started with programming, connect with data science expertise, and more. No appointments required, just walk/drop in!

How does the Data Science Help Desk work?

At the Data Science Help Desk, we can answer general data science questions and connect you with a wealth of data science resources and expertise. The Help Desk is hosted by graduate student TAs of the Data Science Team twice a week on Tuesdays and Wednesdays from 2-3 pm subject to change to fit the needs of the UCSF community. The Data Science Help Desk is open to the UCSF community including faculty, staff, and trainees.

We look forward to meeting you at the Data Science Help Desk!

 

Access Help Desk: Zoom Link

title: Meeting the Moment:  Using AI for Teaching and Learning
description:
Join us for keynote and pre-keynote sessions for the upcoming Teaching and Learning Symposium!

Pre-Keynote Presentation | 9:00 am-10:00 am

Catherine R. Lucey, MD, MACP, Executive Vice Chancellor and Provost, UCSF

Micquel Little, MLIS, MBA, Deputy University Librarian, Library

The pre-keynote session will focus on the latest trends impacting the education community at our university. This session will provide an overview of key developments, such as the integration of technology in the classroom, the rise of remote and hybrid learning models, and the increasing importance of digital literacy. We will also discuss the challenges and opportunities these trends present and share how our institution is actively supporting faculty in navigating these changes. Attendees will learn about new resources, initiatives, and collaborative efforts designed to equip educators with the tools and knowledge they need to thrive in this evolving educational landscape.

Keynote Presentation | 10:00am - 12:00pm

C. Edward Watson, Ph.D., Vice President for Digital Innovation with the American Association of Colleges and Universities

Generative AI tools have had an astonishingly quick impact on the ways we learn, work, think, and create. While higher education’s initial response was to develop strategies to diminish AI’s influence in the classroom, it is now clear that AI competencies and literacies must be embraced as essential learning for most colleges and universities. These responses and realities create a challenging tension that higher education must work to resolve.

Drawing from the presenter’s new book, Teaching with AI: A Practical Guide to a New Era of Human Learning (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2024), this presentation and discussion will detail the challenges and opportunities that have emerged for higher education, especially in terms of pedagogical practice and student engagement. The core focus of this keynote will be on concrete approaches and strategies higher education can adopt, both within the classroom and across larger curricular structures, to best prepare students for the life that awaits them after graduation. It will also detail how faculty can leverage AI to both improve teaching and save time.

Seats are limited for this in-person session of the Teaching and Learning Symposium. Register now to secure your spot and ensure you don’t miss out on this valuable event!

Who Should Join?

The Symposium is intended for UCSF faculty and anyone supporting academic programs at UCSF.

Accommodation

UCSF welcomes people with disabilities to our events and programs. To request reasonable accommodation, please contact Lisa Leiva by emailing Lisa.Leiva@ucsf.edu, as soon as possible.
more_info: Link to view venue location on a map.

title: EdTech Integration: Aligning Tools with Instructional Goals
description:
Join us for an enriching workshop designed to empower educators in selecting UCSF-supported EdTech tools that align with their instructional goals. In this session, we will discuss strategies for leveraging technology to enhance teaching. Whether you aim to streamline your instructional processes or foster a more inclusive and accessible learning environment, this workshop offers valuable insights and practical tips for everyone.

Are you ready to transform your instructional techniques and engage your students like never before? Register now and take the first step towards a more empowered, engaging, and effective instructional experience!

Presenters:

Helen Chen, MS, Instructional Designer, Library

XinXin Huang, MEd, Senior Education Technologist, School of Nursing

Ivory DeWitt, BS, MEd, IT Education User Support Lead, Education IT

Who Should Join?

The Symposium is intended for UCSF faculty and anyone supporting academic programs at UCSF.

Accommodation

UCSF welcomes people with disabilities to our events and programs. To request reasonable accommodation, please contact Lisa Leiva by emailing Lisa.Leiva@ucsf.edu, as soon as possible.

title: Student Panel: What Students Want Faculty to Know
description:
Join us for an insightful session focused on evaluating and improving educational experiences through direct student feedback. This session offers a valuable opportunity to understand how students experience and engage with current learning modalities, including the impact of technology, what influences class attendance, and overall satisfaction. Panelists will share their personal experiences, challenges, and suggestions for enhancing their learning experience. Engage in a dynamic discussion and gain firsthand insights into how we can better support and adapt to the evolving needs of our student community.

Panel Moderators:

Gina Gaiser, MFA, Manager of Digital Teaching & Learning Services

Alexa Tan, MA, Didactic Education Administrator, School of Pharmacy

Silvia Stone, MS, Instructional Designer, Library

Who Should Join?

The Symposium is intended for UCSF faculty and anyone supporting academic programs at UCSF.

Accommodation

UCSF welcomes people with disabilities to our events and programs. To request reasonable accommodation, please contact Lisa Leiva by emailing Lisa.Leiva@ucsf.edu, as soon as possible.

title: Enhancing Teaching with Generative AI: Hands-on Strategies and Tips
description:
Join us for an informative session designed to equip educators with the knowledge and tools to leverage generative AI capabilities for effective teaching. This event will introduce you to AI's fundamental principles and features, specifically focusing on Versa, and demonstrate how it can enhance teaching methods and improve student engagement.

Presenters:

Albert Dang, BA, MFA, Lead Design Strategist Versa AI Team, Education IT

Albert Lee, MADS, Research Solutions Leads Specialist, UCSF IT

Conan MacDougall, PharmD, MAS, Co-Vice Dean of PharmD Education and Associate Dean of Integrated Core Curriculum, School of Pharmacy

Alexa Tan, MA, Didactic Education Administrator, School of Pharmacy

Who Should Join?

The Symposium is intended for UCSF faculty and anyone supporting academic programs at UCSF.

Accommodation

UCSF welcomes people with disabilities to our events and programs. To request reasonable accommodation, please contact Lisa Leiva by emailing Lisa.Leiva@ucsf.edu, as soon as possible.
more_info:
Before You Attend:

To ensure you get the most out of this session, we encourage all attendees to sign up for a Versa account prior to the event. Versa is our interactive platform, which we will use during the workshop to demonstrate real-time applications of generative AI in education. By creating an account, you'll be able to follow along and actively participate in the demonstrations.

Steps to Get Started with Versa:

  1. Sign up for Versa: Please complete the sign-up form to register your interest in using Versa.

  2. Complete the Training: Once registered, you will find a 10-minute Introduction to the Versa training module. This training is crucial as it will help you understand the platform’s functionality and features, and we highly recommend completing it before the workshop to make the most of the session.

  3. Participate Actively: During the workshop, we will have several interactive segments where you can apply what you’ve learned directly in Versa. This hands-on experience is designed to enhance your understanding and confidence in using AI tools for education.

title: Ideation Drawing
description:
Are you interested in learning about visual communication and perspective drawing? Join Makers Lab staff (virtually) covering the process of illustrating basic shapes, 3-point perspective, and shading. 

After attending the 60-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. Define “ideation”
  2. Explain perspective drawing
  3. Draw basic shapes using perspective drawing fundamentals
  4. Demonstrate the ability to apply shading and incorporate light flow

Since this pop-up will be held on Zoom, we are unable to provide supplies. The materials you will need are a straight-edge, a writing utensil, and some paper. To facilitate the learning experience, you are encouraged to share your work during the session.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, please contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

Can’t make it to this pop-up? Self-enroll in the Makers Lab On-Demand CLE course to watch the recording.

Have questions about the Makers Lab? Visit the Makers Lab webpage or contact us. The Makers Lab is open by appointment for UCSF teaching, learning, and research projects. Contact the Makers Lab to schedule an appointment.

title: Curriculum Design & Engaging Our Learners and Creating Belonging​
description:
Our current societal reality provides opportunities to change patterns of exclusion and inclusion in health sciences. Traditional health sciences education has focused on providing knowledge as the way to integrate people into an academic community, but data shows that not all people became equally integrated into this academic community, despite knowledge acquisition. With this in mind, Dr. Estrada will describe findings from her research program in which she has longitudinally tracked and examined what types of mentorships, training experiences, and supports result in students integrating into their professional fields and persisting in health sciences career pathways. Her research focuses on the experiences of persons historically excluded because of ethnicity and race. Further, she will describe practical actions that educators and institutions can take to provide kindness cues that affirm social inclusion. These actions can positively impact the integration experience for historically underrepresented college students, faculty, and administrators in health sciences training and professional settings.

Presenter:

Mica Estrada, PhD, Associate Dean of Diversity, Inclusion and Outreach, School of Nursing

Who Should Join?

The Symposium is intended for UCSF faculty and anyone supporting academic programs at UCSF.

Accommodation

UCSF welcomes people with disabilities to our events and programs. To request reasonable accommodation, please contact Lisa Leiva by emailing Lisa.Leiva@ucsf.edu, as soon as possible.

title: 3D Printing Part 1: Intro to 3D Printing
description:
Are you curious about the applications for 3D printing at UCSF?

Join Makers Lab staff for the first pop-up in a three-part series covering the basics of 3D printing and how the technology can be used in the health sciences.  

After attending the 60-minute pop-up you will be able to:

  1. List the main components of a 3D printer
  2. Identify four methods for obtaining 3D models
  3. Recognize which is the ideal 3D printer for your project
  4. Generate a print time estimate for a given 3D model
  5. Execute a 3D print from start to finish

title: Intro to Vector Art with Inkscape
description:
Have you ever wanted to learn about vector art? Join Makers Lab staff in exploring the basics of Inkscape, a free and open-source vector graphics software alternative to Adobe Illustrator. We will be utilizing various techniques to create vector images for 3D printing, die-cutting, and more!

Please download the latest version of the Inkscape software prior to the pop-up. To facilitate the learning experience, you are encouraged to enable screen sharing

description:

title: 3D Printing & Silicone Casting Demonstration
description:
Join the UCSF Library’s Makers Lab for a virtual demonstration on how 3D printing and silicone casting are being used to create models for UCSF faculty, students, and researchers. The demonstration will be like a cooking show - but for health sciences projects! View the technology in action, learn about projects from UCSF, and ask Makers Lab staff questions!

Attendees do not need to have 3D printing or silicone casting materials for this demonstration.

Register below to receive the Zoom link and password. Contact the Makers Lab if you register for this pop-up and are unable to attend.

All Makers Lab pop-ups are open to the UCSF community. If you are a DPH employee, UCSF alum or retiree, contact the Makers Lab to register for this pop-up.

The UCSF Library is committed to making our events accessible to library patrons. Contact the Makers Lab to request reasonable accommodation for this pop-up.

title: Digital Health Humanities Orientation
description:
This presentation will be an introduction to the Digital Health Humanities Program at UCSF. This course is deigned to onboard new students to the digital tools available to assist in their research, as well as provide an overview in the ways the Digital Health Humanities Program can support their research.

 

This course will cover:

  • What are the Digital Health Humanities?
  • What platforms, tools, and approaches can be valuable for students in their respective programs?
  • What funding is available for digital projects? (HASTAC program)
  • What are research consultations and how can they be used to support emerging scholars?

title: Data Analysis with Python and SQL, Part 1
description:
NOTE: This event is availble to all University of California affiliates and ADHHI scholars. Please register using your university email address if you have one. 

This workshop introduces Python and SQL through a series of common data analysis tasks. Through hands-on programming exercises, participants will learn to import tabular data in CSV and Excel format, specify columns, filter by row value, generate summarizations and descriptive statistics, and create pivot tables. This workshop will also introduce the Google Colab programming environment and strategies for, creating, reviewing, and validating code through Google’s generative AI coding assistant. 

This workshop is part of a broader series covering programming for the digital humanities, with an emphasis on document and text analysis. Although these workshops do not have any formal prerequisites, some background in Python and SQL would be helpful. These workshops will build on material from previous sessions, so it is recommended but not requred to take the workshops in sequence. 

Registration Links: 

  • Data Analysis with Python and SQL, Part 1:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12900575
  • Data Analysis with Python and SQL, Part 2:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901228
  • Reading Data from APIs with Python:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901233
  • Image, Audio, and Video to Text Transcription with Python:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901235
  • Python Background for Text Analysis and Natural Language Processing:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901494
  • Document Classification and Sentiment Analysis using Python and Scikit-Learn
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901511
  • Document Topic Modeling with Python
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901514
  • Classification, Sentiment Analysis, and Topic Modeling using Cloud Based APIs:
    • https://calendars.library.ucsf.edu/event/12901513

This workshop will be offered online through UCSF Zoom and in person at the UCSF Famri Library at Mission Bay. All registrants will recieve an email from libcal with location information and a Zoom link prior to the start of the workshop. You will have the option to attend in person or online regardless of how you register, so please select the option you think is most likely at the time of registration.

title: No and Low Code Approaches to Digital Humanities Research
description:
This session will introduce attendees to the basics of digital health humanities methods by modelling computational methods without the use of computers. In this hands-on session, participants will learn about important digital methods like GIS mapping, network analysis, and text analysis by engaging with prepared archival data. Rather than throwing these students into a class on how to use a digital tool like ArcGIS or Gephi, this workshop will first teach how digital humanists approach their research objects, and how their questions are based out of a humanist tradition.

 

Participants will learn:

  • The basics of a number of digital methods.
  • How research questions can emerge from primary materials.
  • How digital methods inform humanistic research questions, and how these questions critique those digital tools.

title: Data Analysis with Python and SQL, Part 2
description:
NOTE: This event is availble to all University of California affiliates and ADHHI scholars. Please register using your university email address if you have one. 

This workshop introduces more advanced and complex data analysis tasks through Python and SQL, including advanced queries, statistical analytics, regression, correlation, and data visualization. Programming exercises will include hand written code and generative AI code using Google Colab. 

Previous programming experience with Python and SQL is recommended but not required. For an introduction to Python and SQL, please see the 2024 UC Carpentries Fall Workshop Series page at:

https://jt14den.github.io/2024-09-09-UC/

This workshop is part of a broader series covering programming for the digital humanities, with an emphasis on document and text analysis. Although these workshops do not have any formal prerequisites, some background in Python and SQL would be helpful. These workshops will build on material from previous sessions, so it is recommended but not requred to take the workshops in sequence.

description:
NOTE: This event is availble to all University of California affiliates and ADHHI scholars. Please register using your university email address if you have one.

Participants will learn to use open source and cloud based API tools to extract transcripts from different media types, along with methods to evaluate the accuracy and completeness of transcription data. Programming tools will include Jupyter Lab, Google Colab, and Generative AI coding assistants.

title: Data Ethics Workshop
description: This workshop will teach participants how to approach their research in ways that centralize the autonomy of their subjects and their subjects' communities. Participants will be pushed to consider the limitations of current ethical standards (like IRB and informed consent), and pushed to think about how their work depends on the lives, histories, bodies, and cultures of subjects. Built on anticolonial framework, and indebted to Indigenous scholars' critiques of contemporary academic research practices, this workshop will provide an introduction to concepts like refusal and extractive research.

description:

Topics will include string manipulation, data types and conversion, pandas dataframes, and data formatting and preparation. Programming tools will include Jupyter Lab, Google Colab, and Generative AI coding assistants.

title: Document Classification and Sentiment Analysis using Python and Scikit-Learn
description:
NOTE: This event is availble to all University of California affiliates and ADHHI scholars. Please register using your university email address if you have one. 

This workshop will introduce document classification and sentiment analysis using Python and Scikit-Learn. Participants will learn how to build, train, and evaluate a custom supervised machine learning classifier to predict the topic and sentiment of text documents. 

This workshop is part of a broader series covering programming for the digital humanities, with an emphasis on document and text analysis. title: Document Topic Modeling with Python
description:
NOTE: This event is availble to all University of California affiliates and ADHHI scholars. Please register using your university email address if you have one. 

This workshop will introduce topic modeling, a common natural language processing technique used to identify topics within a collection of documents . Participants will use Python, scikit-learn and Gensim to identify hidden patterns and topic clusters within a series of wide-ranging lectures. This workshop will also review methods to read and analyze transcripts from YouTube videos.

This workshop is part of a broader series covering programming for the digital humanities, with an emphasis on document and text analysis. Although these workshops do not have any formal prerequisites, some background in Python and SQL would be helpful. These workshops will build on material from previous sessions, so it is recommended but not requred to take the workshops in sequence.

title: Classification, Sentiment Analysis, and Topic Modeling using Cloud Based APIs
description:
NOTE: This event is availble to all University of California affiliates and ADHHI scholars. Please register using your university email address if you have one. 

This workshop provides and overview of cloud based, hosted APIs that provide generalized, hosted document classification, sentiment analysis, and topic modeling functionality.  Participants will learn how to submit an API request to a pre-trained machine learning or generative AI model, read results for a text document, and evaluate the output.  

This workshop is part of a broader series covering programming for the digital humanities, with an emphasis on document and text analysis. Although these workshops do not have any formal prerequisites, some background in Python and SQL would be helpful. These workshops will build on material from previous sessions, so it is recommended but not requred to take the workshops in sequence.
